prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 imaging of sources in A370

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The primary goal of this proposal is to identify the counterparts to the lensed SCUBA-2 sources. We therefore focus on detection, rather than resolving the sources. At Band 7, we request an intermediate resolution of 0.5 arcsec. This matches the lowest resolution achievalbe in Band 9, and such match is essential for reliable measurments of the spectral slopes of objects.
Band 7 is chosen because of its great sensitivity to the dust spectrum. It matches the waveband of our SCUBA-2 survey (850 um). Its ~17 arcsec primary beam is also adequate for detecting fluxes within the SCUBA-2 positional errors (typically less than 5 arcsec). We will adopt the nominal central frequency of Band 7.
Our SCUBA-2 sources have 850 um fluxes > 2 mJy (Fig. 3), most of which falling in the range of 2-4 mJy. We thus request an rms sensitivity of 0.2 mJy for each source. This sensitivity will provide good ~10 sigma detections on single, compact objects. In the case where a source is slightly resolved, or offset from the pointing center (due to SCUBA-2's positional uncertainty), or split into two objects (e.g., multiple sources in Wang et a. 2011; Karim et al. 2013), we still expect good detections of >5 sigma (per beam) on all our targets. So this 0.2 mJy rms level is required to guarantee detections of all the SCUBA-2 sources and unambiguous identifications of their counterparts.
We do not request special calibrations.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 imaging of sources in A1689

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The primary goal of this proposal is to identify the counterparts to the lensed SCUBA-2 sources. We therefore focus on detection, rather than resolving the sources. At Band 7, we request an intermediate resolution of 0.5 arcsec. This matches the lowest resolution achievalbe in Band 9, and such match is essential for reliable measurments of the spectral slopes of objects.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 imaging of sources in A2390

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The primary goal of this proposal is to identify the counterparts to the lensed SCUBA-2 sources. We therefore focus on detection, rather than resolving the sources. At Band 7, we request an intermediate resolution of 0.5 arcsec. This matches the lowest resolution achievalbe in Band 9, and such match is essential for reliable measurments of the spectral slopes of objects.
Band 7 is chosen because of its great sensitivity to the dust spectrum. It matches the waveband of our SCUBA-2 survey (850 um). Its ~17 arcsec primary beam is also adequate for detecting fluxes within the SCUBA-2 positional errors (typically less than 5 arcsec). We will adopt the nominal central frequency of Band 7.
Our SCUBA-2 sources have 850 um fluxes > 2 mJy (Fig. 3), most of which falling in the range of 2-4 mJy. We thus request an rms sensitivity of 0.2 mJy for each source. This sensitivity will provide good ~10 sigma detections on single, compact objects. In the case where a source is slightly resolved, or offset from the pointing center (due to SCUBA-2's positional uncertainty), or split into two objects (e.g., multiple sources in Wang et a. 2011; Karim et al. 2013), we still expect good detections of >5 sigma (per beam) on all our targets. So this 0.2 mJy rms level is required to guarantee detections of all the SCUBA-2 sources and unambiguous identifications of their counterparts.
We do not request special calibrations.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 9 imaging of sources in A370

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Among our 53 highly amplified SCUBA-2 850 um sources, only 16 brighter ones are also detected at 450 um. We thus proposal Band 9 imaging to accurately determine the 680 GHz fluxes of all our targets to better constrain their FIR SEDs. We will use the nominal frequency of Band 9.
To reach the best surface brightness sensitivity, we request the lowest angular resolution at Band 9, 0.5 arcsec. This is also our requested resolution for Band 7.
Among the SCUBA-2 sources that are detected at both 450 um and 850 um, their mean 450um/850um flux ratio is ~4. So we need to be able to detect fluxes of >8 mJy at 680 GHz, given that our targets are brighter than 2 mJy at 850 um. However, our source identification and detection will be primarily done at Band 7 at high S/N levels. With the source positions accurately determined in Band 7, their Band 9 detections can be easily confirmed even if the S/N in Band 9 is lower. We therefore only request a Band 9 rms of 1.2 mJy. After folding in the positional uncertainty of SCUBA-2 (typically less than 5 arcsec), we expect detections of 4-7 sigma even on the fainter ones of our sources.
We do not request special calibrations.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The advent of SCUBA-2 on JCMT has for the first time allowed us to efficiently map a large area at 850 um down to the confusion limit. At the same time, the gravitational lensing of massive clusters is a powerful tool for probing faint, high-redshift objects at all wavelengths. Our deep SCUBA-2 surveys in three z~0.3 lensing cluster fields (A370, A1689, and A2390) have produced a unique sample of 53 850um-selected objects that are highly magnified by the clusters. They have intrinsic fluxes stretching down to ~0.1 mJy, which is the flux level required to fully account for the submillimeter backgound. This flux also corresponds to the luminosity regime occupied by normal galaxies selected in the rest-frame UV. We propose to image the 53 strongly lensed SCUBA-2 sources with ALMA at Band 7 and Band 9, to identify their optical counterparts, constrain their far-IR properties, and better determine the source counts, at a flux level much lower than existing surveys in the black fields. With the proposed imaging, combined with rich multiwavelength data for the three clusters, we can make detailed descriptions of the faint submillimeter galaxy population that are the dominant star formers.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica
